questions.text: A baby presents with chronic diarrhea and a rash resembling acrodermatitis on the skin. Based on the clinical picture, what is the most likely deficiency?
questions.solution:
Zinc deficiency can lead to acrodermatitis enteropathica, a rare genetic disorder that presents with:

  • Chronic diarrhea
  • Periorificial and acral dermatitis (rash around the mouth, hands, feet, and perineal area)
  • Alopecia
  • Failure to thrive and immune dysfunction

It occurs due to impaired zinc absorption and can also be seen in cases of inadequate dietary intake or prolonged parenteral nutrition without zinc supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Selenium deficiency (Option B) : Causes cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease) and muscle weakness, but not chronic diarrhea or acrodermatitis.

 

Niacin deficiency (Option C): Leads to pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 D’s"—diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia—but the rash is typically photosensitive, unlike acrodermatitis.


Magnesium deficiency(Option D): Presents with neuromuscular symptoms like tetany, seizures, and arrhythmias rather than a characteristic rash and chronic diarrhea.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents with complaints of multiple soft, pedunculated masses scattered across his torso and limbs. The parents mention that the child has recently developed some difficulty in reading and learning. Upon examination, the child has hyperpigmented macules with irregular borders on his back, and the ocular exam shows the findings below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) NF1

Explanation:

The child presents with:

  • Multiple soft, pedunculated masses → Likely neurofibromas
  • Hyperpigmented macules with irregular borders → Café-au-lait spots
  • Ocular findings (likely Lisch nodules on iris examination)
  • Learning difficulties

These findings are characteristic of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17, which encodes neurofibromin (a tumor suppressor protein).

Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1)

  • Incidence: 1 in 3,000 live births.
  • Inheritance:
    • 50% of cases are inherited from a parent.
    • 50% due to spontaneous mutations.
  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11.2. The gene encodes neurofibromin, which inhibits the oncogene Ras.

Diagnosis Criteria (Two or more required)

Feature

Description

Café-au-lait macules (CALMs)

>5 mm in prepubertal, >15 mm in postpubertal.

6 or more needed for diagnosis

Axillary/Inguinal Freckling

Multiple hyperpigmented areas, 2-3 mm in diameter.

Iris Lisch Nodules

Hamartomas in the iris, best seen with a slit-lamp.

2 or more needed for diagnosis

Neurofibromas

Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma.

Osseous Lesion

Sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones.

Congenital pseudarthrosis of the tibia.

Optic Gliomas

CNS tumor affecting the optic nerve.

 

Family History

First-degree relative with an NF1 diagnosis based on these criteria.

Management

  • Regular Monitoring:
  • Treatment Considerations:
    • Avoid routine brain/optic tract imaging unless symptomatic.
    • Selumetinib: Effective in children with inoperable plexiform neurofibromas.
  • Neuropsychological and Educational Support.

Genetic Counseling

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant; over 50% of cases are de novo mutations.
  • Molecular Testing:
    • Useful in cases with unclear clinical diagnosis or severe disease.
    • Prenatal/preimplantation diagnosis may be considered.

NF2 (Neurofibromatosis Type 2) (Option A): NF2 is associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas, hearing loss, and juvenile cataracts, rather than café-au-lait spots and Lisch nodules. It is caused by a mutation in the NF2 gene (Merlin protein) on chromosome 22.

TSC1 (Tuberous Sclerosis Complex 1) (Option B): TSC1 is associated with hamartomas, facial angiofibromas, hypopigmented “ash-leaf” macules, and cortical tubers, not café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas. It is due to a mutation in the TSC1 gene (hamartin) on chromosome 9.

TSC2 (Tuberous Sclerosis Complex 2) (Option C): Similar to TSC1, TSC2 presents with hypopigmented macules, facial angiofibromas, and neurological issues like epilepsy but is due to a mutation in the TSC2 gene (tuberin) on chromosome 16.

questions.text:
Match the Incubation periods of the following diseases:


	
		
			
			a. Syphilis
			
			
			1. 16 days
			
		
		
			
			b. SARS
			
			
			2. 90 days
			
		
		
			
			c. Hepatitis A
			
			
			3. 6 days
			
		
		
			
			d. Chickenpox
			
			
			4. 28 days
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1

Explanation:

Disease

Incubation period

a. Syphilis

2. 90 days

b. SARS

3. 6 days

c. Hepatitis A

4. 28 days

d. Chickenpox

1. 16 days

questions.text: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhoea and alopecia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Zinc

  • Zinc deficiency leads to poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia due to its role in cell division, immune function, and tissue repair.

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica (a genetic disorder of zinc absorption) presents with periorificial and acral dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia.

  • Zinc is crucial for collagen synthesis, immune function, and enzyme activity, making its deficiency detrimental to healing.

Zinc Deficiency

Feature

Zinc Deficiency

Causes

Poor diet, malabsorption (Crohn’s, celiac), chronic diarrhea, alcoholism

Clinical Features

Poor wound healing, dermatitis, alopecia, diarrhea, immune dysfunction

Dermatological Signs

Eczematous plaques, periorificial dermatitis, nail dystrophy

Diagnosis

Low serum zinc, clinical presentation

Treatment

Zinc supplementation (oral zinc sulfate)

Iron (Option A): Incorrect because iron deficiency causes anemia, fatigue, koilonychia, and glossitis, not dermatitis and diarrhea.

Calcium (Option B): Incorrect because calcium deficiency leads to tetany, muscle spasms, and osteomalacia, not alopecia or poor wound healing.

Magnesium (Option C): Incorrect because magnesium deficiency causes neuromuscular excitability, tremors, and cardiac arrhythmias, not dermatitis or alopecia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with the following skin lesions characterized by red and scaly patches. The patient also complains of a painful and swollen finger joint. On examination, the finger joint appears inflamed and tender to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Psoriatic Arthritis

  • The image shows dactylitis (sausage digit), which is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

  • The patient has red and scaly skin lesions, suggesting psoriasis.

  • Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, affecting small and large joints, with dactylitis, enthesitis, and nail changes.

  • Dactylitis is a hallmark feature of PsA, caused by inflammation of both tendons and joints.

Psoriatic Arthritis

Feature

Psoriatic Arthritis

Etiology

Autoimmune, associated with HLA-B27

Joint Involvement

Asymmetrical, affects DIP, PIP, and spine

Key Features

Dactylitis (sausage digit), enthesitis, nail pitting, onycholysis

Skin Lesions

Psoriasis (scaly plaques on extensor surfaces)

Diagnosis

CASPAR criteria, RF negative, elevated ESR/CRP

Treatment

NSAIDs, DMARDs (Methotrexate, Sulfasalazine), Biologics (TNF-α inhibitors)

Pseudo gout (Option B): Incorrect because pseudo gout presents with acute monoarthritis (e.g., knee) due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition, but does not cause dactylitis or skin lesions.

Osteoarthritis (Option C): Incorrect because OA affects weight-bearing joints, spares DIP, and lacks systemic inflammation like psoriasis.

Reactive Arthritis (Option D): Incorrect because reactive arthritis follows an infection (e.g., GI or GU) and presents with conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis (Reiter’s syndrome), but lacks dactylitis and psoriasis.

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Phrynoderma

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • History of night blindness (suggests vitamin A deficiency).

    • Follicular hyperkeratotic papules, typically on extensor surfaces.

  • Classic Appearance:

    • Resembles "toad skin" (hence, phrynoderma).

    • Associated with malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency.

  • Most Likely Diagnosis: Phrynoderma (Follicular hyperkeratosis due to vitamin A deficiency).

 

Phrynoderma (Vitamin A Deficiency)

 

Feature

Details

Definition

Follicular hyperkeratosis due to Vitamin A deficiency

Causes

Malnutrition, fat malabsorption, chronic diarrhea

Clinical Features

Keratotic papules on extensor surfaces, rough skin, night blindness

Diagnosis

Clinical, serum Vitamin A levels

Treatment

Vitamin A supplementation, improved nutrition

Keratosis pilaris (Option B): Incorrect because it is a benign genetic condition without a history of vitamin A deficiency.

Darier disease (Option C): Incorrect because it presents with greasy crusted papules, not vitamin A-related follicular hyperkeratosis.

Follicular eczema (Option D): Incorrect because eczema is associated with itching, scaling, and lichenification, not night blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhoea and alopecia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Zinc

  • Zinc deficiency can indeed cause poor wound healing, dermatitis (inflammation of the skin), diarrhea, and alopecia (hair loss).
  • Zinc is essential for immune function, wound healing, and maintaining healthy skin and hair.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Iron: Iron deficiency is associated with anemia, fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. It can lead to reduced oxygen transport in the body, causing symptoms like tiredness, shortness of breath, and cold extremities.

Option B - Calcium: Calcium deficiency can result in weak bones, brittle nails, and muscle cramps. It's crucial for maintaining bone health and proper muscle function.

Option C - Magnesium: Magnesium deficiency may lead to muscle spasms, irregular heartbeat, and weakness. It plays a role in nerve transmission and muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which mineral deficiency can potentially cause the condition depicted in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Zinc – Treatment – 30-50 mg elemental zinc

The condition is known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, it is a condition where due to a deficiency of zinc in the body of the children leads to allergic skin lesions. The treatment for this is 30-50 mg of elemental zinc to be given to the baby.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B: iron - Generally in the case of iron deficiency leading to an anemia component in the patient, the skin appears pale or there may be tiny red or purple dots on the skin in a case of aplastic anemia and even pruritus ( itchy skin) may be present which when scratched gives a red, swollen skin.

Option C: Calcium - Whereas in the case of calcium deficiency for a long time may lead to brittle nails along with dry and cracked skin. Apart from skin, there may be a coarse texture of the hair and even psoriasis, alopecia, and eczema.

Option D: vitamin A - Apart from delayed growth and development in a child and night blindness due to a deficiency of vitamin A components, dry, scaly, and itchy skin also occurs. In females, there may be problems associated with fertility and conception.

questions.text: The following lesion was noticed in a patient with a history of involuntary weight loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by thickened, darkened patches of skin. These patches often have a velvety texture and can occur in various areas of the body, such as the neck, armpits, groin, and skin folds. Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with insulin resistance, which can be seen in conditions like type 2 diabetes or as a result of obesity.

Incorrect options :

Option B. Leser-Trélat sign refers to the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, which are benign skin growths. This sign is associated with underlying malignancies, particularly gastrointestinal cancers, but it does not specifically indicate involuntary weight loss.

Option C. Actinic keratosis is a precancerous skin condition characterized by rough, scaly patches that develop due to long-term sun exposure. While it can be associated with certain types of skin cancer, it is not directly related to involuntary weight loss.

Option D. Intertriginous Candida refers to a fungal infection that occurs in areas of skin-on-skin contact, such as the groin, armpits, or under the breasts. It typically presents as red, itchy, and moist lesions, but it is not typically associated with involuntary weight loss.

questions.text: What is the cause of cutis marmorata?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Exposure to cold temperature

  • Exposure to cold temperature: Cutis marmorata is a condition characterized by a mottled or reticulated appearance of the skin.
  • It occurs due to the dilation of capillaries and venules in response to cold temperature.
    • This is a normal physiological response to cold exposure and is commonly observed in infants and young children.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Humidity: Humidity does not directly cause cutis marmorata. However, changes in humidity can sometimes affect the appearance of the skin, particularly in individuals with underlying skin conditions or sensitivities.

Option C - Exposure to hot temperature: Cutis marmorata is not typically associated with exposure to hot temperatures. It is more commonly seen in response to cold temperatures.

Option D - An adverse reaction to drugs: While certain medications can cause skin reactions, cutis marmorata is not specifically associated with adverse drug reactions. It is primarily related to temperature-induced changes in blood vessel constriction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?

choices.text: The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d’ orange appearance of the skin be seen
Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds phenomenon

questions.solution:
Correct Option D:Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds phenomenon

  • "Scleredema is associated with sclerodactyly or Raynaud's phenomenon." This statement is false.
  • Scleredema is a distinct condition and should not be confused with scleroderma, which is associated with sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers) and Raynaud's phenomenon (vasospasm of blood vessels in response to cold or stress).

Incorrect Options:

Option A: "The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal." This statement is true for scleredema. Scleredema is characterized by thickening of the dermis, resulting in a firm, indurated texture of the skin.

Option B: "Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen." This statement is also true for scleredema. Erythema (redness) and a peau d'orange (orange peel) appearance of the skin are commonly observed in scleredema.

Option C: "Scleredema can occur in association with diabetes." This statement is true. Scleredema can be associated with various underlying conditions, including diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A patient came with fever, body ache, and joint pain. He was given NSAIDS. A few days later, he developed brownish pigmentation over the nose. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D

  • Chikungunya is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, particularly the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus species. The symptoms of Chikungunya typically include fever, body ache, and joint pain, which are similar to those described in the scenario.
  • One characteristic feature of Chikungunya is the development of brownish pigmentation over the nose, known as "Chikungunya pigmentation." This pigmentation is a specific dermatological manifestation associated with the infection and can occur during the acute or subacute phase of the disease. It is believed to be due to the deposition of hemosiderin, a pigment derived from the breakdown of red blood cells, in the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A Melasma: Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by brownish or grayish pigmentation on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is typically triggered by hormonal changes, such as during pregnancy or with the use of hormonal contraceptives. Melasma is not directly related to the symptoms described in the scenario or to the use of NSAIDs.

Option B Fixed drug eruption (FDE): Fixed drug eruption is a type of drug reaction characterized by the development of well-defined skin lesions after the administration of a particular medication. These lesions typically recur at the same site(s) each time the drug is taken. Brownish pigmentation may occur as part of the healing process, but the key feature of FDE is the recurrent appearance of the lesions at specific locations. The scenario does not mention any recurring skin lesions associated with drug intake, making FDE an unlikely diagnosis.

Option C Dengue: Dengue is another viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, particularly the Aedes mosquito. The symptoms of dengue include fever, body ache, and joint pain, which are similar to those described in the scenario. However, the development of brownish pigmentation over the nose is not a characteristic feature of dengue. Instead, dengue is known for causing other dermatological manifestations, such as a rash and red spots on the skin.

questions.text: A mother has a pearly white papule on her forehead which her infant also develops. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option : B

  • A pearly white papule on the forehead of both the mother and her infant is suggestive of a condition called Molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by the Pox virus. Molluscum contagiosum is a common viral skin infection that primarily affects children, but it can also occur in adults.
  • Molluscum contagiosum presents as small, flesh-colored or pearly white papules on the skin. These papules often have a central depression or "dimple" and can appear anywhere on the body, including the forehead. The infection is highly contagious and can be transmitted through direct skin-to-skin contact or by sharing personal items like towels or clothing.

Incorrect options:

Option A) HPV (Human Papillomavirus): While HPV can cause various types of skin lesions, including warts, it is not typically associated with pearly white papules on the forehead resembling Molluscum contagiosum. HPV commonly causes genital warts, plantar warts, and common warts on hands or feet, but it is not the primary cause of Molluscum contagiosum.

Option C) Adenovirus: Adenovirus is a common respiratory virus that can cause a range of symptoms, including respiratory infections, conjunctivitis (pink eye), and gastroenteritis. It is not associated with pearly white papules on the skin like Molluscum contagiosum.

Option D) Herpes virus: Herpes viruses, including herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2, can cause oral and genital lesions, but they typically present as grouped vesicles (blisters) rather than pearly white papules. Herpes infections are characterized by recurrent episodes of painful blisters or sores, whereas Molluscum contagiosum appears as discrete papules.

questions.text: A child patient comes to OPD with history of black central arch rashes on his body, what is your diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option A.

  • Meningococcemia is a bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Neisseria meningitidis. It is characterized by the presence of a petechial or purpuric rash, which appears as black central arch rashes on the body. The rash occurs due to small areas of bleeding under the skin, known as petechiae, that darken over time.

Incorrect option 

Option B, Dengue hemorrhagic fever: Dengue fever is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. While it can cause a rash, it typically presents as a maculopapular rash that is not characterized by black central arch rashes. Additionally, dengue hemorrhagic fever is a severe form of dengue that involves bleeding, but the rash pattern described in the question is not associated with dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Option C, Leptospirosis: Leptospirosis is a bacterial infection caused by the spirochete bacteria of the genus Leptospira. It can cause a range of symptoms, including fever, muscle pain, and rash. However, the rash in leptospirosis is typically a maculopapular rash and does not typically present as black central arch rashes.

Option D, Scrub typhus: Scrub typhus is an infectious disease caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is transmitted through the bite of infected mites. The characteristic rash in scrub typhus is an eschar, which is a dark, crusted lesion at the site of the mite bite. It does not typically present as black central arch rashes.
